facebook_headline: No, Donald Trump isn't donating his kidney to Melania
ruling_comments:
An online hoax says that President Donald Trump is planning to donate his kidney to his wife, Melania, but the story is made up.

"BREAKING NEWS: Donald Trump On His Way To Donate Kidney To Melania Trump," said a May 14 headline on news-hawaii.com.

Facebook flagged this story as part of its efforts to combat false news and misinformation on Facebook's News Feed. (Read more about our partnership with Facebook.)

Melania underwent kidney surgery May 14, but the story takes the saga further by claiming that a second kidney replacement became necessary after doctors found out during the surgery that both her kidneys were destroyed.

"Trump would be undergoing medical examination and if declared fit as a donor, he will proceed to donate to save his wife Melania," according to the story.

The story cites a White House press statement as evidence of the procedure, but that was made up, too. We did not find any mention of it on the official White House website. And no other major news outlets reported anything about it.

Trump actually tweeted May 14 (the same date the hoax published) that Melania was recovering well after her procedure.

"Heading over to Walter Reed Medical Center to see our great First Lady, Melania. Successful procedure, she is in good spirits. Thank you to all of the well-wishers!" he tweeted.

See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com

Trump is not planning on donating a kidney to Melania. We rate this Pants on Fire!

See Figure 2 on PolitiFact.com
ruling_headline: No, Donald Trump isn't donating his kidney to Melania
sources:
CNN, Melania Trump undergoes kidney surgery at Walter Reed medical center, May 14, 2018

News-hawaii.com, BREAKING NEWS: Donald Trump On His Way To Donate Kidney To Melania Trump, May 14, 2018
statement: "BREAKING NEWS: Donald Trump On His Way To Donate Kidney To Melania Trump."

subject.description:
There’s an interesting discussion happening now about the spread of fake news on the Internet and what companies like Facebook, Google and Twitter, among others, should do to stop it.

That’s a healthy conversation to have, and one we hope continues in the weeks and months ahead.

But that doesn’t mean we can’t do something now. Here at PolitiFact, we’re beefing up our coverage of fake news to help our readers better sort out fact from fiction on their social media feeds.

The claims can be about anything -- politics, entertainment, a fishy-sounding medical cure.
subject.subject: Fake news

twitter_headline: No, Donald Trump isn't donating his kidney to Melania
